_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Green River Valley Water District has on file a Risk Management Plan in conjunction with the Hart County LEPC. Employees are trained by Brenntag Chemical Company in the proper handling of a chemical leak. Emergency equipment on hand include 30-minute Scott Air-Pak breathing apparatus, rubber boots, gloves, face shields, splash-proof safety googles. In case of an accidental release, Community Responders are trained to OSHA's "Awareness" and "Operations" with some "incident Management System" level by the Kentucky TECH/Fire and rescue Training  Branch. The local radio stations and television station would be notified in case of such accident.



Chlorine is transported by truck on I-65, the Louie B. Nunn Parkway and US 31E to the Green River Valley Water Treatment Plant by Brenntag Chemical Company,1405 Highway 136 W, P.O. Box 20, Henderson Ky. 42419-0020. A maximum of approximately 10,000 lbs. are handled and stored.



With any accidental release, if the door to the facility can be closed safely, the spill will be contained in the chlorine room. A water spray can be directed at the vapors, not the point of leak, to reduce vapors. The water spray runoff can be contained and neutralized with soda ash. The Hart Co. LEPC would be contacted for the spill containment and the cleanup and disposal would be accomplished per EPA and Kentucky Department of Natural Resources regulations. The facility's hazardous materials clean-up will be First Response, 1052 Searcy Way, Bowling Green, Ky 270-793-0906, 24 hr. emergency, 1-800-914-9111. If not available, Chemtrec would be called to activate Chlorep (Chlorine Emergency Response Team) to clean up the spill. Any cleanup of hazardous waste will be accomplished through a plan approved by KY Natural Resources and/or US EPA. The distance to the endpoint (under worst case weather) the substance could travel 2.2 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public.

y leaks and the employees of the Green River Valley Water District have safety meetings regarding chemical safety and procedures for the proper use of the emergency equipment on site. Community responders are trained to OSHA's "Awareness and Operations" with some "Incident Management System" Level by the Kentucky TECH/Fire and Rescue Training Branch.



The Green River Valley Water District has not had any chlorine release in the past 5 years.



Facility response points will consist of two locations,(south end) which will be the primary location at the old Rodgers Store in Canmer, North of Hwy 677 and 31E. The facility representative who meets the off-site response personnel shall have a copy of the Title II Plan, the facility contingency plan, safety data sheets and should brief the responders on the current situation. This response plan was developed through the joint efforts of the Green River Valley Water District and the Hart Co LEPC and Hart Co Fire Dept.



During the 2019 Process Hazard Analysis and the 2020 Compliance Audit, a number of recommendations were made to decrease the likely hood that a release could occur.  The changes resulting from the recommendations will improve the safety of the chlorine process and provide further protection of the operators.
